symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses. Infections, allergies, and various conditions can lead to sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Restless Legs Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder that causes a strong urge to move one's legs. This urge often comes with unpleasant feelings in the legs, and moving them relieves the discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Periodontal Disease
diagnoses.description: A serious gum infection that damages gums and can destroy the jawbone. It's often a result of poor oral hygiene.

diagnoses.name: Seizure Disorders (Epilepsy)
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which nerve cell activity in the brain is disturbed, causing seizures. There can be many causes, including genetics, brain injury, and others.

diagnoses.name: Leukocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by an increased number of white blood cells in the bloodstream, often an indicator of infection or other diseases.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Could be related due to chronic diseases.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It's associated with disorders like hypertension and diabetes but can be related to systemic conditions causing leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the body's immune system attacks healthy cells. Can lead to various symptoms, including leukocytosis, fatigue, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in high blood sugar (glucose), which can cause symptoms like increased hunger, thirst, and urination, as well as fatigue and blurred vision.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency
diagnoses.description: The most common cause of anemia, which can result from chronic blood loss as seen in periodontal disease, leading to fatigue, pallor, and more.

diagnoses.reasoning: Celiac disease can cause malabsorption, contributing to symptoms such as attention deficit due to nutrient deficiencies. It can also lead to easy bleeding due to vitamin K deficiency.
This condition can cause attention deficit, easy bleeding due to decreased platelet production, and oral pain from glossitis or mouth ulcers.
Characterized by easy bleeding, oral pain, and attention deficit issues due to reduced oxygen supply to the brain.
Can cause non-restorative sleep and attention deficit due to poor quality sleep; indirectly linked to malabsorption if associated with obesity.
Known for causing non-restorative sleep, attention deficit, and easy bleeding due to potential concomitant immune dysfunctions.
Can cause non-restorative sleep and attention deficit; oral pain may stem from associated temporomandibular joint disorders.
A rare disorder causing oral pain (mouth ulcers), attention deficit, and possibly easy bleeding.
Conditions such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis can lead to malabsorption, oral pain (mouth ulcers), and easy bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract.
A type of cancer that can cause easy bleeding, attention deficit (due to anemia), and non-restorative sleep.

Can indirectly cause attention deficit, non-restorative sleep, and contribute to oral pain (due to lack of self-care or bruxism), and easy bleeding (due to neglect in nutrition and health maintenance).

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Features include hyperactivity, weight loss, and it may go along with psychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Storm
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening health condition that is associated with untreated or under-treated hyperthyroidism. During thyroid storm, an individual's heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature can soar to dangerously high levels.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and makes excessive amounts of thyroid hormone. This can lead to symptoms such as weight loss, hyperactivity, and heart palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Anxiety disorders can present with symptoms such as restlessness, excessive worry, and may coincide with symptoms like hyperactivity and obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat over and over.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome, this is a genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and visible red or purple spots on the skin (telangiectasias), alongside various other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that control heart rate, metabolism, and blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.description: Characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it. This disorder might also lead to or intensify other symptoms in this context.

diagnoses.name: Primary Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: Occurs when one or more of the parathyroid glands become overactive. It can lead to various symptoms including bone loss, kidney stones, and psychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A neurodevelopmental disorder affecting both children and adults. It is characterized by persistent problems such as hyperactivity, impulsiveness, and difficulties in maintaining attention.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Syncope (various causes including vasovagal syncope, cardiac arrhythmias)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include aphasia, numbness, and paresthesia depending on the area of the brain affected.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It involves an immune-mediated process in which an abnormal response of the body’s immune system is directed against the central nervous system. Symptoms can include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, partial or complete loss of vision, prolonged double vision, tingling or pain, and in some cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances such as visual disturbances, sensory symptoms like tingling or numbness, speech disturbances including aphasia, and more. These symptoms typically precede the headache phase of the migraine attack.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can press on nerve tissues and affect brain function. Symptoms may include headaches, seizures, paralysis, numbness, speech problems (aphasia), and sensory changes (such as hearing loss or paresthesia), depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can cause aphasia, numbness, or paresthesia, but unlike a stroke, the symptoms typically disappear within 24 hours without leaving permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Hearing Loss
diagnoses.description: While hearing loss itself is a condition, it can sometimes be a symptom of more complex issues like neurodegenerative diseases, certain viral infections, or trauma. It's essential to assess hearing loss in conjunction with other symptoms like aphasia, numbness, or paresthesia for accurate diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: Meniere's disease affects the inner ear and can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In rare cases, it may also cause sensations of numbness or tingling (paresthesia), but it is not typically associated with aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: Neurosyphilis is a bacterial infection of the brain or spinal cord. It can occur in people who have had untreated syphilis for many years. Symptoms might include abnormal gait, numbness, weakness, headaches, dementia, hearing loss, and in advanced stages, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. Late-stage Lyme disease can affect the nervous system, causing symptoms such as facial palsy (which might be confused with numbness), meningitis, impaired muscle movement, and in rare cases, hearing issues and cognitive defects.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that develops on the cranial nerve that runs from your brain to your inner ear and controls balance and hearing. Symptoms can include hearing loss, ringing in your ear, dizziness, and loss of balance. In large tumors, additional symptoms such as numbness, paralysis of facial muscles, or paresthesia might occur.

diagnoses: Vasculitis affecting the central nervous system
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.
A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.
A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, noted by intense, debilitating headaches.
Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain.
A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection.
An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection.
An infection of the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.
A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain, which can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).
A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.

diagnoses: HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia)
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to autoimmune disorders
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with other autoimmune manifestations
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)
